travels.title: France '10
travels.headertext: After leaving Seattle on Wednesday, May 19, we didn't arrive in Lyon until late Thursday night May 20. We spent Friday and Saturday exploring Lyon by foot.

entry.text: On Sunday morning, May 23, we picked up a car and left Lyon (A) headed to our next stop: St. Nectaire. We took the _Q_long way_Q_. We started out early on the motorway south out of Lyon. Sunday morning was good for avoiding any traffic. We went as far as Saint-Etienne and the little town of Firminy (B) where we exited the motorway to take some smaller roads. The area is very scenic with rolling hills and small villages. The weather was perfect. We headed west towards Apinac (C), stopping at a small village (St. Hilaire?) for pastries along the way. From Apinac, we continued south to Cappone-sur-Arzoa (D) and Saint-Paulien (G). Just outside of Le Puy-en-Valay (F), we ran across the fortress at Polignac which we viewed from the highway. We didn't have time to go explore it further. After visiting Le Puy-en-Valay and having lunch, we headed back north, backtracking to Saint-Paulien before turning more northwest to Monlet (H) and Chaise-Dieu (I). We drove by the very large, well-known abbey at Chaise-Dieu, but again didn't have time to explore. We passed through St. Germain L'Herm and Issoire before arriving in the evening at St. Nectaire (J). As we arrived in St. Nectaire, we noticed traffic coming out of the town was heavy. It had been a festival weekend in St. Nectaire, and judging by the crowds just leaving, arriving Sunday evening was excellent timing. By a couple hours later, the town was much quieter and much more comfortable. We stayed at an excellent B_AND_B called Villa Hubert.

entry.text: On Monday, we explored the towns in the northern portion of the Auvergne. We started by driving up the road to Le Mont-Dore (H). The weather was wonderful, so we got some picnic supplies in Le Mont-Dore, then took the funicular up the mountainside. We hiked the rest of the way to Le Capucin. There are beautiful scenes along the way and from the top of Le Capucin. We had our picnic while waiting for the funicular back down. We were going to take the cablecar up to Puy de Sancy, but it didn't seem to be running. Instead, we headed further west to La Bourboule (C). They also had a cablecar which we took up for nice views of the valley. We then headed over to Murat-le-Quaire (D) and La Banne d'Ordanche (E) on the north side of the valley. We drove to the parking lot of La Banne, which had nice views, but decided not to climb to the top of the peak since we wanted to go to the gardens at the Chateaux at Rochefort-Montagne and it was getting late. We drove to the Chateaux (F), but were already too late...it was closed. We took a small road a couple kilometers over to Orcival (G), which was a charming little village. We then headed back to Le Mont-Dore and St. Nectaire (I), passing Roche Sanadoire along the way

entry.text: Tuesday (May 25) we did a loop around the Puy de Sancy. We started out by again passing through Le Mont-Dore (H). The weather was still wonderful, so we got more picnic supplies. From Le Mont-Dore we headed southeast to the Valee de Chaudefour (C) where we did a short hike in the beautiful valley. After a picnic lunch in the valley, we continued to Besse-et-Saint-Anastaise (D). After Besse, we stopped by the pretty little lake of Lac Pavin. Its in the remains of an old crater (a small version of Crater Lake, OR). By Lac Pavin, some clouds had come in and it was starting to rain. We continue in our circle to the small towns of Chastreix (F) and La Tour-d'Auvergne (G). From there, it was back to Le Mont Dore and St. Nectaire (I).

entry.text: Wednesday, May 26, we moved from St. Nectaire to Belcastel, a small village to the south on the Aveyron. The route we took was fairly direct from St. Nectaire (A) through Murol (B) to Condat (C) and Riom-es-Montagnes (D). We stopped in Riom for a pastry and found the Wednesday market in full form. It was a true local market, not touristy like we found in some places. Lots of produce for sale, not to mention the ducks, rabbits, fish and other animals. From Riom, we crossed over the incredibly scenic Pas de Peyrol (E). The road was sort of scary: windy, narrow and perched on the edge of a cliff, but the views! We stopped at the souvenir store/restaurant at the pass for a look around. We were planning on walking to the Puy Mary peak (about 45 minutes), but the path was closed and the weather was threatening, so we stuck to the pass area. From the pass, we went down to Salers (F). Along the way, we had to pull to the side of the road as a family herded their cattle to a new pasture. All the cows had huge cow bells which made for great sight and sound (although not smell) as they went by. We had lunch in Salers then continued to Aurillac (G), Decazeville (H) and Belcastel (I). We stayed at Hotel du Vieux Pont, which is a very nice place with a one-star Michelin restaurant with it. We had dinner there that night. Extraordinary food! I had the cod (unfortunately, French don't seem to understand extraordinary vegetarian food).

entry.text: Thursday, May 27, was one of our busiest days. We covered a lot of ground. We started out by going up to the small town of Rignac (B) for breakfast at a little patisserie. We then went back south to join one of the main roads headed to Villenfranche-du-Rouergue (D), Limogne-en-Quercy (E) and Grotte de Pech Merle (F). They had a very nice market day in Villenfranche when we stopped in there. Villenfranche is a _Q_bastide_Q_ town, meaning the central square is fully encircled by buildings. That was the heart of the market and very interesting. In the Grotte de Pech Merle we got to see 30000 year old Cro-Magnon cave paintings. I especially like the negative hand prints. After our tour of Pech Merle, we backtracked a bit to St. Cirq Lapopie (G), a small, scenic town perched on the cliffs above the river. It was a very nice town, but much more a tourist town than many of the small towns we'd seen up to this point. After St. Cirq, we followed the river back east to Cajarc (H), then headed through Figeac (I) and Maurs (J) on our way to Conques (K). Conques was another scenic town perched on a hillside. We had dinner in Conques, then headed back through Decazeville (L) to Belcastel (M).

entry.text: On Friday (May 28), we travelled from Belcastel to Sergeac. We started out looking for breakfast. We passed through Rignac (B), but had breakfast there the day before and decided to keep going. We tried Montbazens (C), but didn't see anything open we liked, so we continued to Decazeville (D). The road however turned off shortly before the center of Decazeville, so we didn't get anything there either. Finally, we stopped in Figeac (E) where we found a salon de the and had some pastries. After our now late breakfast, we continued to Gramat where we visited their zoo and had a picnic lunch. The zoo focused on European animals and was very interesting. The wolves were very active and fun to watch. The zoo also had lots of local breeds of farm animals. It was interesting to see all the different breeds of ducks, pigs, chickens, horses, cows, goats, etc. After the zoo, we continued to Payrac (G) and Sarlat-la-Caneda (H). We were going to stop in Sarlat, but the Friday night traffic was so horrific, we just passed on to Segerac (J) via Les Eyzies (I). We arrived at Hotel Castel Merle in time for dinner. We liked the dinner so much we decided to have Sunday dinner here also.

entry.text: We'd driven so much in the last couple days that we decided to take Saturday (May 29) a little easier. We started just up the road from Sergeac (A) at Montignac (B) which is a bustling town with a Saturday market. We also went out to Saint-Amand (C) before returning for our scheduled tour at the Cro-Magnon caves of Lascaux (D). Lascaux is where they actually have a replica of the actual cave, which they had to close to preserve. The art at Lascaux is more extensive and colorful than at Pech Merle, but also has a lot of similarity. After our tour, we came back to Montignac, then drove out to Fanlac (E), a small town that turned out to be seemingly deserted when we arrived there in the late afternoon. After a quick walk around Fanlac, we came back to Thonac (F) for a quick look at its church before heading further south to Les Eyzes where we had dinner. After dinner, it was back to Sergeac.

entry.text: Sunday (May 30) was another busy day. We wanted to go back east to see Rocamadour and the Gouffre de Padirac. Because of the distances and because we'd already travelled some of these roads, we decided to hit the motorway. From Segerac (J), we went through Montignac (B) and joined the motorway (C). It was then a quick trip east to Brive and then south to the exit towards Martel (H) and Rocamadour (E). Rocamadour is beautifully built into the cliffs, but is such a tourist town! Also, it was Sunday, so services were in session and we didn't get to look inside the church. After Rocamadour, we headed to the Gouffre de Padirac (F), having lunch just before getting there. The cave is huge, reminscent of the caves we saw in Slovenia. Part of the tour is a gondola ride on the river running through the cave, which was fun. After the cave tour, we headed out to the Chateaux at Castelnau (G). It beautifully perched above the river valley. We took a tour (in French) of some of the rooms of the Chateaux. From the Chateaux, we hurried back to the motorway to get back to Sergeac in time for our dinner at the hotel.

entry.text: Monday (May 31) was another travel day. This time we went from Sergeac to St. Emillion. We started by going to Sarlat (B), which we bypassed on Friday because traffic was so bad. Monday morning was quiet in the old-town of Sarlat, which was nice. We checked out the church, the lantern building and the rest of the old city. Although it's a nice town, I thought we saw nicer one's elsewhere without the overwhelming tourist feel of Sarlat. Our next stop after Sarlat was Beynac-et-Cazenac (C) and Chateaux de Beynac. The castle goes back to the 12th century. After Beynac, we headed directly west where we stopped at Lalinde for lunch. From Lalinde (D) we went directly to St. Emillion (E). We wanted to get to St. Emillion early enough to take one of the tours of the _Q_underground_Q_ church. The church in St. Emillion is _Q_monolithic_Q_, it was honed directly out of the limestone instead of being built stone by stone, hence its underground. The only way to see much of the structure is on one of the tours. The tour was interesting, but we got there too late for an English tour, so we went on the French version. I wasn't able to follow much of it. We had dinner in St. Emillion before returning to our hotel, Chauteaux Meylet, just outside the city.

entry.text: Tuesday (June 1) was our last full day in France. Instead of going into Bordeaux, which we heard really wasn't worth it, we decided to go to the coast. Arcachon (B) is the largest town over there, so we headed for it. We looked around Arcachon, then drove down the coast via the seaside town of Pyla-sur-Mer (C) to the La Dune du Pilat (D). The dune was fascinating and fun. You really get great views from the top of it, which you reach via a stairway. We had a picnic lunch at the dune. After the dune, we continued down the coast to the beach at Biscarosse (E). We went out to the beach to see the Atlantic. From the beach, we headed back toward Arcachon and went along the bay to Gujan-Mestras (F). Next we headed back toward St. Emillion, which meant going by Bordeaux (G). Traffic on the ring road around Bordeaux was terrible in the morning and even worse in the evening. We decided to try to go through the center of Bordeaux. We got completely lost, but it did give us a chance to see Bordeaux. When we finally found our way out the other side, we went to Libourne (H) for dinner before returning to St. Emillion.
